In MOST cases, it would be uniform and a net of zero. However, at the edge of a galaxy, stars have a radial speed that indicates they SHOULD be shooting off into space. This is an observed phenomenon.

Usually, it's Command (cmd) = Control and Option (opt) = Alt. The letters are the same. So, for example, Cmd-Shift-C (pre-compose) will be Ctrl-Shift-C.

There's also HitFilm, but it's $399 (express is $149), which is still really steep, plus I don't know whether it's capable of doing particle simulations like this. Either way, both programs have free trials.
Also, I forgot to mention, the trial of After Effects is limited on some plug-ins. I don't know if any of the ones used in the tutorial are not in the trial (they probably are, but I've never installed the trial myself).

The trial lasts 1 month. If you want to do what FreddieW did, you can get a computer, get the trial, and when it runs out, just reinstall your operating system and download it again. It's pretty impractical, but if you just want to do this particle simulation, a 1 month trial is more than plenty long enough.

Go to Adobe's website, click Products at the top of the page, scroll down to the list of products, look for After Effects CS6, and click on it.
